name: squash history
info:
Combines history data from the start index and most recent index into a new history array.

Inputs

start number
The index of the starting history value. It can be set as an environment variable in the subflow properties. Default value is 0.

Outputs

history array
An array containing two elements - the starting history value based on the specified index, and the most recent history value.

Details

The subflow first retrieves the 'start' value from the environment variables. The starting history value is fetched based on this index, and the latest history value is retrieved as well. The function then creates a new array containing these two values and sets it as the output message 'history' property.

name: function 1
func:
msg.history = [msg.history[env.get('start')],msg.history[msg.history.length - 1]]
return msg;

name: requirements
template:
I need a node-red subflow according to the following Specification:

msg.payload starts as an array of node-red node objects with the following properties:

id,
type,
z (optional)

I want this to be transformed into an array of new objects, one for each 'subflow' type in the incoming message.

the new objects should have:
id: the id of the subflow
nodes: a deep clone of the subflow node, and all nodes with the subflows 'id' as their 'z' property

type: 'subflow'

please provide me with a valid, syntactically correct JSON string that I can use to import the subflow above

name: sort eligible for doc
documentation
template:
I have the following node-red subflow: ```json {{{payload}}} ``` here are some facts about it: {{{analysis}}} Please provide a brief html document to describe it: start with a brief description of no more than three sentences, use the following three sections as necessary: inputs, outputs, and details here's an example document that describes the "read file" subflow: ```html

Reads the contents of a file as either a string or binary buffer.

Inputs

filename string
The name of the file to be read can be provided in the node configuration, or as a message property. By default it will use msg.filename but this can be customised in the node.

Outputs

payload string | buffer
The contents of the file as either a string or binary buffer.
filename string
If not configured in the node, this optional property sets the name of the file to be read.

Details

The filename should be an absolute path, otherwise it will be relative to the working directory of the Node-RED process.

On Windows, path separators may need to be escaped, for example: \\Users\\myUser.

Optionally, a text file can be split into lines, outputting one message per line, or a binary file split into smaller buffer chunks - the chunk size being operating system dependant, but typically 64k (Linux/Mac) or 41k (Windows).

When split into multiple messages, each message will have a parts property set, forming a complete message sequence.

Encoding of input data can be specified from list of encodings if output format is string.

Errors should be caught and handled using a Catch node.

``` inputs/outputs should refer only to properties on messages that move through the flow. put environment variable descriptions into the 'details' section. take care to be sure that the behavior you report is actually what the subflow does. remember to respond with html.

name: set system message
template:
You are an expert in node-red, flow based programming, and javascript.
The user will provide you with a json string of a node-red subflow.

analyze the subflow and respond with a detailed description of:
- a description of every node in the subflow, including input and output.
  - the name or id of the node
  - the type of the node, 
    - if the node is a function node, include an analysis of the javascript in the "func" property
  - how the node is configured 
  - the node(s) it recieves messages from.
    - Note: nodes do not list in their own JSON what nodes they recieve messages from. you'll have to inspect the other nodes for output id that matches the node
  - the node(s) it sends messages to.
- all environment variables that may be set on instances of the subflow
- all necessary and optional properties on incoming messages.
- all properties that may exist on outgoing messages

finally, end with a summary description of the subflow, based on the detailed information you've gathered.

organize your response in sections.

name: system input
template:
You are an expert in node-red, flow based programming, and javascript.
The user will provide you with a detailed description of a node-red subflow.

respond with a JSON schema to validate incoming messages to the subflow.
respond with ONLY the valid JSON text, without preamble or postscript.
the first character in your response should be '{'

name: system output
template:
You are an expert in node-red, flow based programming, and javascript.
The user will provide you with a detailed description of a node-red subflow.

respond with a JSON schema to validate outgoing messages from the subflow.
respond with ONLY the valid JSON text, without preamble or postscript.
the first character in your response should be '{'

name: system info
template:
You are an expert in node-red, flow based programming, and javascript.
The user will provide you with a detailed analysis of a node-red subflow.

respond with a user focused description of the subflow with the following structure:
- A brief description of the functionality of the subflow as a whole
- An "Input" section describing the input message requirements and how they're used
- An "Output" section describing the output message properties and what they are
- A "Details" section with instructions on how to use any environment variables, as well as any other relevant information for someone who wishes to use the subflow.

name: parse
format
template:
You are an html formatter. The user will present you with a piece of documentation you must respond with an html representation of the document here is an example for css and structure reference:

Reads the contents of a file as either a string or binary buffer.

Inputs

filename string
The name of the file to be read can be provided in the node configuration, or as a message property. By default it will use msg.filename but this can be customised in the node.

Outputs

payload string | buffer
The contents of the file as either a string or binary buffer.
filename string
If not configured in the node, this optional property sets the name of the file to be read.

Details

The filename should be an absolute path, otherwise it will be relative to the working directory of the Node-RED process.

On Windows, path separators may need to be escaped, for example: \\Users\\myUser.

Optionally, a text file can be split into lines, outputting one message per line, or a binary file split into smaller buffer chunks - the chunk size being operating system dependant, but typically 64k (Linux/Mac) or 41k (Windows).

When split into multiple messages, each message will have a parts property set, forming a complete message sequence.

Encoding of input data can be specified from list of encodings if output format is string.

Errors should be caught and handled using a Catch node.

respond with ONLY the valid HTML, without preamble or postscript. the first character in your respose should be '<'

name: function 4
func:
msg.payload = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify([msg.payload,msg.payload]))

return msg;

template:
You are an expert in node-red, flow based programming, and javascript.
You are also an expert in fuzz testing.
The user will provide you with a detailed description of a node-red subflow, as well as JSON schemas for the input and output messages.

respond with a JSON array containing 10 subarrays:
- each subarray should contain two objects:
    - first, a sample input according to the input schema
    - second, the expected output according to the output schema and the description of how the subflow works

these pairs you generate will be used to fuzz test the flow, so you should include a variety of samples that cover different cases.

respond with ONLY the valid JSON text, without preamble or postscript.
the first character in your response should be '['
